question: Question_01_(c)
statement:
Consider the function

\[\displaystyle
f(x,y) = e^{-x^{2} + 4y^{2}}\]

c) Find the tangent plane approximation to the value of $f(1.99, 1.01)$
using the tangent plane from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/December_2011/Question_01_(b)}{part
(b)}.
sols:
From
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/December_2011/Question_01_(b)}{part
(b)}, we found that the tangent plane to the surface $z = f(x,y)$ at the
point $(2,1)$ was

\[\displaystyle -4x + 8y - z = -1.\] Since the point $(1.99,1.01)$ is
very close to $(2,1)$, the tangent plane approximation gives a good
estimate for the true value of $f(1.99,1.01)$. Plugging in
$(x,y) = (1.99,1.01)$ into the tangent plane equation we get

\begin{align*}
 -4(1.99) + 8(1.01) - z &= -1\\
 -7.96 + 8.08 - z &= -1\\
 0.12 - z &= -1 \quad \rightarrow \quad z = 1.12
\end{align*} Therefore,

\[{\color{blue}f(1.99,1.01) \approx 1.12}.\]
hints:
The tangent plane you derived in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/December_2011/Question_01_(b)}{part
(b)} should provide a good estimate for \emph{f(x,y)} for values of
\emph{(x,y)} near \emph{(2,1)}. Simply plug in the values of
\emph{(x,y)} into your tangent plane approximation to estimate
$z = f(x,y)$.
